importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the article's publication, marking the latest update on the Mariners' postseason progress and Suárez's historic grand slam.
The 1995 American League Division Series victory over the Yankees is referenced as a pivotal moment in Mariners history, believed to have saved baseball in Seattle.

The 2001 ALCS, specifically Game 4, is cited as a historic moment when Bret Boone hit a game-tying homer, a precedent that the current article references as a benchmark for dramatic postseason moments.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current postseason in 2025 is the context in which the article takes place, highlighting the Mariners' near-miss at the World Series and the significance of Suárez's grand slam.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning to give the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 win over the Toronto Blue Jays.
This is the second grand slam in Mariners postseason history, marking a significant milestone for the franchise.
The Mariners now lead the best-of-seven series 3-2, with just one more win needed to reach the World Series – their first time being within one win of the Fall Classic in franchise history.
The Mariners have never reached the World Series, making this achievement especially historic and emotionally charged for fans.
Suárez's performance was emotional and symbolic, as he spoke to his two daughters and wife, emphasizing personal and familial significance.
Cal Raleigh’s earlier homer in the eighth inning tied the game, and his performance is noted as a rare and dramatic moment in Mariners postseason history.
This game marks a turning point in the series, with the Mariners returning to Toronto for Game 6 on Sunday night.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eugenio Suárez hit a game-tying grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, giving the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays and pushing them to within one win of their first World Series appearance in franchise history. The Mariners, who have never reached the Fall Classic, now lead the series 3-2 and are set to return to Toronto for Game 6. The win follows a dramatic series of events, including a game-tying homer by Cal Raleigh and earlier runs by George Springer and Ernie Clement. Suárez’s performance was emotionally charged, with him speaking to his family and highlighting the personal and historic significance of the moment. The article draws parallels to past moments in Mariners history, such as the 1995 ALDS and 2001 ALCS, emphasizing how this current moment echoes the franchise’s long-standing pursuit of postseason success.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
